matched.actualTitle: Hardcoded SSH Credentials Exposed in Source Code
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability: hardcoded SSH credentials (hostname: 'localhost', port: 22, username: 'pedro', password: 'AHeavySandbag' base64 encoded as 'QUhlYXZ5U2FuZGJhZw==') exposed in the application source code. Both highlight exposure through the unauthenticated /source endpoint and the critical impact of credential exposure leading to unauthorized SSH access and system compromise.

extra.title: Flask Application Source Code Disclosure via /source Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - A critical information disclosure vulnerability allowing unauthenticated access to complete application source code through the /source endpoint. This is a separate but related vulnerability to hardcoded credentials, as it exposes the full application logic, configuration, and enables discovery of the hardcoded SSH credentials.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Unauthenticated Exposure of Server Process Information
extra.assessment: New discovery - The root endpoint exposes detailed server process information without authentication, including UIDs, PIDs, CPU/memory usage, and full command lines. This is a reconnaissance vulnerability separate from the hardcoded credentials but related to the debug information exposure theme.

extra.title: Flask Application Running with Debug Mode Enabled
extra.assessment: New discovery - Flask is configured to run in debug mode, which enables Werkzeug debugger and exposes detailed error pages and debugging information. This is a security misconfiguration vulnerability separate from but enabling other attacks.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing six critical security headers: X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, and Referrer-Policy. This indicates poor security practices and reduces defense against client-side attacks.

extra.title: Insecure Application Server Configuration - 0.0.0.0 Binding
extra.assessment: New discovery - The Flask application is bound to all network interfaces (0.0.0.0) instead of localhost, and is running using Flask's development server instead of a production WSGI server. This creates unnecessary network exposure.

extra.title: Werkzeug Debug Console PIN Authentication Bypass & Remote Code Execution
extra.location: Flask Werkzeug debugger console at /console endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - A critical vulnerability in Werkzeug's debug console that can be bypassed using a calculated PIN based on predictable machine information. This leads to remote code execution as the application user with full system access. This is a sophisticated exploitation of the debug mode vulnerability.
